review.title: A Collaborative Mechanism for Crowdsourcing Prediction Problems
review.abstract: Machine Learning competitions such as the Netflix Prize have proven reasonably successful as a method of "crowdsourcing" prediction tasks. But these competitions have a number of weaknesses, particularly in the incentive structure they create for the participants. We propose a new approach, called a Crowdsourced Learning Mechanism, in which participants collaboratively "learn" a hypothesis for a given prediction task. The approach draws heavily from the concept of a prediction market, where traders bet on the likelihood of a future event. In our framework, the mechanism continues to publish the current hypothesis, and participants can modify this hypothesis by wagering on an update. The critical incentive property is that a participant will profit an amount that scales according to how much her update improves performance on a released test set.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The last few years have revealed a new trend in the field of "machine learning": prediction and learning problems rolled into price categories. One of the first, and certainly the most well-known, was the Netflix Prize, which was released in the fall of 2006. Netflix, which aims to improve the algorithm used to predict the preferences of users in its database of movies, has sent a dataset of 100M ratings to the public and asked competing teams to submit a list of prediction results that are withheld from the public. Netflix offered $1,000,000 to the first team to exceed a certain threshold, a goal that was finally met. We propose a weaker term, which we call a general scoring rule L (·, ·), which is intended to reflect the loss function of the learning problem at hand. We then describe the CLM framework, especially the important case when a CLM implements a general scoring rule L. We provide a set of properties and results for L-CLMs.
